conversation.content: Look, I've got—I've got a charge here. Twenty-seven fifty. That's not right.

Course it did. Look. Job starts Monday. Need this cleared up.
Got it.
I'm probably—probably not explaining this right. It's a duplicate. For primer.

No no you're explaining fine, I'm tracking this now, the system shows two charges for product code PRM-4487-GL which is the industrial primer five-gallon, both hitting your card ending in 8829 but only one shipment actually processed.
Exactly. Exactly exactly. One shipment. Two charges.

Right so what I'm doing—I'm doing a manual override here, canceling that duplicate charge immediately with confirmation number CNC-5509-XR21 and you should see that reflected within twenty-four to forty-eight hours on your statement.
Twenty-four to... that's what they said. Last time.
I think—let me try something different here, instead of waiting for the standard reversal I can process this as priority code P7 which basically forces it through in about two hours max.
Two hours. Okay. Okay okay. If—if it actually works.
It will.
Sorry. Just. Been calling about this. Three times now.

Totally understand that frustration, I'm noting this entire history in ticket TKT-0938-FV44 and flagging it for management review, plus I'm setting up an automatic alert to verify the refund processes correctly by end of business today.
And if it doesn't? Monday's coming. I need—I need supplies ordered.

Here's what I'll do, I'm giving you my direct extension 4-7-2-9-1 and case reference REF-8823-NZ, and if this isn't showing cleared by five PM today you call me directly and I'll process your supply order manually bypassing the payment hold.
Direct line. Right. We'll—we'll see if someone answers.
Someone will, that's me until eight PM Eastern today and I've got your account flagged priority status PST-901 so it'll pop right to the top of my queue, you won't wait more than one ring.

scenario: house painter, patient but needing to resolve a supply charge before his next job
